In contrast to the quasi-historical subjects with fictional overlays which had filled the Venetian stage for a half century, Metastasio's works were characterized by inevitable conflicts of personal affection and patriotic duty, the seemingly insoluble moral dilemmas they posed, and denouements hinging on seemingly unimportant physical cues which led to a central moment of revelation.
Metastasio's works soon became so firmly entrenched in  the opera world that many dominated European stages for the balance of the century.

745: Girolamo Medebach succeeded the Gozzi, and he in turn engaged Carlo Goldoni (1748-49) to write fully scripted comedies.

The audience response to Goldoni, after its preceding year under the Gozzi, was so striking that Sant' Angelo signed Goldoni on to a four-year contract in March 1749.
Goldoni's advertised reform of comedy precipitated a pamphlet war which began as soon as these contracted works began, in the autumn of 1749.
The rivalry between Goldoni and his nemisis, Pietro Chiari, which grew more bitter every year, did not peak until 1760.
Goldoni's discontents at Sant' Angelo led him to move to San Salvatore in 1753 on a ten-year contract.
Medebach responded to Goldoni's abandonment by hiring Chiari at Sant' Angelo.
A legal dispute between Medebach and Goldoni's publisher, Bettinelli, clouded three theatrical years, from the autumn of 1753 until Lent 1756.
The subtleties of character and language in the social satires of Goldoni and some of his contemporaries were such that utmost care in dress, language, and gesture was required in  portrayals.
The bitter insults which increasingly flew between Chiari, Goldoni, and occasionally the Gozzi engaged public interest and thereby increased the readership of printed editions.
It was a roost not for the dramma per musica but rather for the collabora- tions of Goldoni and a native son, Baldassare Galuppi.
Despite Goldoni's tenure as a dramatist there, San Salvatore produced more operas in the 1750s than it had in recent decades.
Opere buffe and comedies remained popular to the extent that they were performed well, though once Goldoni left the city, there was considerably less public discussion about prose theater.
